user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of digest_get_hash_size:
```c
_MHD_static_inline size_t
digest_get_hash_size (enum MHD_DigestAuthAlgo3 algo3)
{
#ifdef MHD_MD5_SUPPORT
  mhd_assert (MHD_MD5_DIGEST_SIZE == MD5_DIGEST_SIZE);
#endif /* MHD_MD5_SUPPORT */
#ifdef MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT
  mhd_assert (MHD_SHA256_DIGEST_SIZE == SHA256_DIGEST_SIZE);
#endif /* MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT */
#ifdef MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT
  mhd_assert (MHD_SHA512_256_DIGEST_SIZE == SHA512_256_DIGEST_SIZE);
#ifdef MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT
  mhd_assert (SHA256_DIGEST_SIZE == SHA512_256_DIGEST_SIZE);
#endif /* MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT */
#endif /* MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT */
  /* Only one algorithm must be specified */
  mhd_assert (1 == \
              (((0 != (algo3 & MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_MD5)) ? 1 : 0)   \
               + ((0 != (algo3 & MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA256)) ? 1 : 0)   \
               + ((0 != (algo3 & MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA512_256)) ? 1 : 0)));
#ifdef MHD_MD5_SUPPORT
  if (0 != (((unsigned int) algo3)
            & ((unsigned int) MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_MD5)))
    return MHD_MD5_DIGEST_SIZE;
  else
#endif /* MHD_MD5_SUPPORT */
#if defined(MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT) && defined(MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT)
  if (0 != (((unsigned int) algo3)
            & ( ((unsigned int) MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA256)
                | ((unsigned int) MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA512_256))))
    return MHD_SHA256_DIGEST_SIZE; /* The same as SHA512_256_DIGEST_SIZE */
  else
#elif defined(MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT)
  if (0 != (((unsigned int) algo3)
            & ((unsigned int) MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA256)))
    return MHD_SHA256_DIGEST_SIZE;
  else
#elif defined(MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT)
  if (0 != (((unsigned int) algo3)
            & ((unsigned int) MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA512_256)))
    return MHD_SHA512_256_DIGEST_SIZE;
  else
#endif /* MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT */
    (void) 0; /* Unsupported algorithm */

  return 0; /* Wrong input or unsupported algorithm */
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (0 != (((unsigned int) algo3)            & ((unsigned int) MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA512_256)))
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 14.3 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The controlling expression depends on the function parameter 'algo3' (cast to unsigned int) and the mask macro MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA512_256, so it is not inherently invariant in normal use. Therefore the rule is not violated. A specific violation scenario would be if the mask macro were defined as 0 (so the condition becomes if (0 != (algo3 & 0)) → if (0 != 0), always false) or if the call were made with a compile-time constant 'algo3' such that the expression is provably constant; in those cases the controlling expression would be invariant and would violate Rule 14.3.
